questions.question: Which of the following best defines a design pattern?
questions.option_a: A. A proven solution to a common software design problem in a given context
questions.option_b: B. A ready-made algorithm for solving any coding issue
questions.option_c: C. A reusable template for recurring design challenges
questions.option_d: D. A detailed implementation for all problems
questions.explanation: Design patterns are standardized, reusable solutions to common design problems that occur in software architecture within a specific context—not full implementations or universal algorithms.

questions.question: Why are design patterns important in software development?
questions.option_a: A. They provide proven, reusable solutions
questions.option_c: C. They eliminate the need for design thinking
questions.option_d: D. They enhance communication among developers
questions.explanation: Design patterns improve code quality by offering tested approaches, reduce complexity through abstraction, and serve as a shared vocabulary among developers—but they do not replace design thinking.

questions.question: Who introduced the concept of design patterns to software engineering?
questions.option_a: A. Christopher Alexander
questions.explanation: Christopher Alexander pioneered the pattern concept in architecture; the Gang of Four (Gamma, Helm, Johnson, Vlissides) adapted it to software engineering in their seminal 1994 book.

questions.question: Which of the following are key components of a design pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Name
questions.explanation: A design pattern is typically described using four elements: Name (for identification), Problem (when to apply), Solution (structure/relationships), and Consequences (trade-offs).

questions.question: What does the ‘Name’ component of a design pattern represent?
questions.option_a: A. Identifies the pattern and helps communication
questions.option_d: D. Explains how to reuse the pattern
questions.explanation: The name provides a shared vocabulary that allows developers to quickly refer to and discuss recurring solutions without explaining the entire structure each time.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the ‘Problem’ component of a design pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Explains when to apply the pattern
questions.option_b: B. Specifies what issue the pattern solves
questions.option_c: C. Defines the relationships among classes
questions.explanation: The Problem section describes the specific design challenge and contextual conditions under which the pattern is applicable.

questions.question: Which classification deals with object creation?
questions.option_a: A. Creational
questions.explanation: Creational patterns (e.g., Singleton, Factory) focus on mechanisms for creating objects while increasing flexibility and reuse.

questions.question: Which classification deals with how classes and objects are composed?
questions.option_a: A. Creational
questions.explanation: Structural patterns (e.g., Adapter, Composite) concern the composition of classes or objects to form larger structures while maintaining flexibility and efficiency.

questions.question: Which classification deals with communication among objects?
questions.option_a: A. Behavioral
questions.explanation: Behavioral patterns (e.g., Observer, Strategy) focus on how objects interact, distribute responsibility, and communicate.

questions.question: Which of the following are Creational design patterns?
questions.option_a: A. Singleton
questions.explanation: Singleton, Factory Method, Builder, and Abstract Factory are all Creational patterns; Observer is a Behavioral pattern.

questions.question: Which statement defines the Singleton Design Pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Ensures a class has only one instance
questions.option_b: B. Provides a global access point to that instance
questions.option_c: C. Allows multiple instances for performance
questions.option_d: D. Guarantees thread safety by default
questions.explanation: The Singleton pattern restricts instantiation to one object and provides a global point of access to it, but thread safety must be explicitly implemented.

questions.question: How is Singleton implemented in Java?
questions.option_a: A. Private constructor
questions.explanation: A Java Singleton uses a private constructor to prevent external instantiation, a static variable to hold the single instance, and a static accessor method (e.g., getInstance()).

questions.question: Which real-world scenarios represent Singleton?
questions.option_a: A. The President of a country
questions.explanation: Singletons model entities that must be unique in a system—e.g., a country has one president, a system typically has one file manager or print spooler.

questions.question: Which are advantages of using the Singleton pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Saves memory by reusing a single instance
questions.option_b: B. Ensures centralized control of shared resources
questions.explanation: Singletons conserve resources and offer global access, but they often complicate testing due to global state and tight coupling.

questions.question: Which are disadvantages of Singleton?
questions.option_a: A. Difficult to test due to global state
questions.option_b: B. Can lead to tight coupling
questions.option_c: C. Limits flexibility in large systems
questions.option_d: D. May lead to excessive use and poor design
questions.explanation: Singletons introduce global state, reduce modularity, and can mask poor architectural choices if overused; thread safety is also a common pitfall.

questions.question: Which statement defines the Observer Pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Defines one-to-many dependency between objects
questions.option_b: B. When one object changes state, dependents are notified automatically
questions.option_c: C. Defines how objects are instantiated
questions.option_d: D. Enables direct inheritance between objects
questions.explanation: The Observer pattern establishes a subscription mechanism to notify multiple objects (observers) about state changes in a subject without tight coupling.

questions.question: Which are core components of the Observer pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Subject
questions.explanation: The Observer pattern includes an abstract Subject (manages observers), Observer interface (defines update method), and their concrete implementations.

questions.question: Which statements describe the Subject class in Observer pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Maintains a list of observers
questions.option_b: B. Provides methods to add/remove observers
questions.option_c: C. Notifies observers on state change
questions.explanation: The Subject manages observer registration and notifies them upon state changes; it does not implement the Observer interface—that’s the role of ConcreteObserver.

questions.question: Which real-world system demonstrates the Observer pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Social media follower notifications
questions.explanation: In social media, users (observers) subscribe to posts or updates from accounts (subjects)—a classic one-to-many notification model matching the Observer pattern.

questions.question: Which are advantages of the Observer pattern?
questions.option_a: A. Promotes loose coupling between objects
questions.option_b: B. Enables dynamic subscription and unsubscription
questions.explanation: Observer decouples subjects from observers, supports runtime subscription changes, and streamlines broadcast communication—but does not guarantee update order.
